citation.article-title: Characterization of Desulfomicrobium salsuginis sp. nov. and Desulfomicrobium aestuarii sp. nov., two new sulfate-reducing bacteria isolated from the Adour estuary (French Atlantic coast) with specific mercury methylation potentials

p.s: Description of Desulfomicrobium aestuarii sp. nov.
id="section_lbl4.4.1">a.es.tu.a’ri.i. L. n. aestuarium estuary; L. gen. n. aestuarii of the estuary
Cells are motile short rods (0.6–0.7×1.0–3.0 μm).
Growth occurs from 10 to 40 °C (optimum, 35 °C) and at NaCl concentrations ranging from 0 to 40 g l−1 (optimum, 5 g l−1).
Sulfate, thiosulfate and nitrate are used as electron acceptors.
Fumarate and DMSO are not used as electron acceptors.
Lactate, formate, malate and H2 serve as electron donors.
Malate is fermented, pyruvate poorly but not fumarate.
The G+C content of the DNA is 64.1 mol% (HPLC).
The type strain is ADR26, isolated from estuarine intertidal sediments, deposited in the DSMZ and JCM collections under accession numbers DSM19191 and JCM14714, respectively.
